Lee Meyer with a super clever idea using scroll-driven animations as an interaction to "like" or "dislike" something.

(This is a sponsored post.)
Itâ€™s probably no surprise to you that CSS-Tricks is (proudly) hosted on Cloudways, DigitalOceanâ€™s managed hosting arm. Given both CSS-Tricks and Cloudways are part of DigitalOcean, it was just a matter of time â€¦

Today, I want to look into one of those cases of impatient and how the community has waited for that feature, to be specific, two upcoming functions: sibling-count() and sibling-index().

articles.description:
I wrote a post for Smashing Magazine that was published today about this thing that Chrome and Safari have called â€œTight Modeâ€ and how it impacts page performance. Iâ€™d never heard the term until DebugBearâ€™s Matt Zeunert mentioned it in â€¦

articles.author: Andy Bell
articles.description:
I am still an AI skeptic. The biggest risk I foresee is thatÂ if your sole responsibility is to write code, your job is at risk. Itâ€™s not time to panic, but I do see a lot of value in evolving your soft skills.

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
I'm more thankful this time around because, last year, I didn't even get to write this post. But now that I'm back, writing this feels so, so, so good. There's a lot more gusto going into my writing when I say: thank you so very much! Let's tie a bow on this year and round up what happened around here in 2024.

2024 has been one of the greatest years for CSS: cross-document view transitions, scroll-driven animations, anchor positioning, animate to height: auto, and many others. It seems out of touch to ask, but what else do we â€¦
A CSS Wishlist for 2025 originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez
articles.description:
Today, I want to focus on what I'll call the little triangle in the tooltip. It receives minimal attention but it amazes you by how many ways there are to make them. Let's start with the simplest and make our way up to the not-so-simple.
The Little Triangle in the Tooltip originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Fatuma Abdullaho
articles.description:
When was the last time you developed a multi-step form? Thereâ€™s so much to think about and so many moving pieces that need to be managed. But doing it by hand can be a good exercise and a great way to polish the basics. Fatuma Abdullaho walks you through her first multi-step form using vanilla HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
How to Create Multi-Step Forms With Vanilla JavaScript and CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: How to Create Multi-Step Forms With Vanilla JavaScript and CSS

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
What else do we want or need CSS to do? Chris kept a CSS wishlist, going back as far as 2013 and following back up on it in 2019. We all have things we'd like to see CSS do and we always will no matter how many sparkly new features we get. We'll round things up and put a list together â€” so let us know!
What ELSE is on your CSS wishlist? originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
